review.title: Learning Graphical Games from Behavioral Data: Sufficient and Necessary Conditions
review.abstract: In this paper we obtain sufficient and necessary conditions on the number of samples required for exact recovery of the pure-strategy Nash equilibria (PSNE) set of a graphical game from noisy observations of joint actions. We consider sparse linear influence games --- a parametric class of graphical games with linear payoffs, and represented by directed graphs of n nodes (players) and in-degree of at most k. We show that one can efficiently recover the PSNE set of a linear influence game with $O(k^2 \log n)$ samples, under very general observation models. On the other hand, we show that $\Omega(k \log n)$ samples are necessary for any procedure to recover the PSNE set from observations of joint actions.

sections.heading: 4.4. Necessary Conditions
sections.text: In this section we derive necessary conditions for the number of samples required to learn graphical games. Our approach to this is information theory: we treat the inference method as a communication channel and then use the fano inequality to reduce the estimation error. Such techniques have been widely used to obtain necessary conditions for model selection in graphical models, see e.g. [13, 14], the splinter yield in linear regression [15], and many other problems.
